arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized in 20 series: Hosea Ballou 2d; Alonzo Ames Miner, records; Elmer Hewitt Capen, administrative records and related papers; Frederick William Hamilton, administrative records and related papers; William Leslie Hooper, administrative records and related papers; Hermon Carey Bumpus, administrative records and related papers; John Albert Cousens, administrative records and related papers; George Stewart Miller, administrative records and related papers; Leonard Carmichael, administrative records and related papers; Nils Yngve Wessell, administrative records and related papers; Leonard Chapin Mead, administrative records and related papers; Burton Crosby Hallowell, administrative records and related papers; Jean Mayer, administrative records and related papers; John DiBiaggio, administrative records and related papers; Historical presidential correspondence; Artifacts; Annual report of the president; Lawrence Seldon Bacow, administrative records and related papers; Anthony P. Monaco administrative records and related papers; and Unprocessed accessions.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: All material accessioned prior to 1997 was originally arranged by subject by Russell Miller. No attempt was made to recreate original order, although material relating to administering the collection was removed to the documentation files of the collection in the archives. Also, some material in the early presidents' records were assembled from other sources when the material was brought into the library in the late 1960s.

The busts of Hosea Ballou, Alonzo Ames Miner, and Elmer Hewitt Capen, which had been on loan from the Art Gallery, were returned to them on May 7, 2018, by Collections Management Archivist Adrienne Pruitt.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: All material accessioned prior to 1997 was originally arranged by subject by Russell Miller. No attempt was made to recreate original order, although material relating to administering the collection was removed to the documentation files of the collection in the archives.

Related to series 013, Jean Mayer administrative records and related papers: The 8 boxes originally cataloged as MS 144, Jean Mayer papers were integrated into UA001.013 in March-April 2014 by Dan Bullman, under the supervision of Susanne Belovari (Archivist for Reference and Collections). These boxes are now labeled UA001.013.039-44; unprocessed material: UA001-102, UA001-103). The decision was taken because MS144 in fact contained a mix of Jean Mayer's presidential files, research files and personal records as well as folders related to the newspaper column. MS144 was dissolved after these files were moved to UA001.013. However in doing so, we did not reorganize or relabel the material because the overall series needs more detailed processing and rearrangement in order to differentiate between Jean Mayer's records as Tufts president and his research and other files. Rusty paperclips and staples were removed at accession. Records in boxes 41 and 42 are water damaged and have indications of non-active mold.

Digital audio-visual material in the Anthony P. Monaco administrative records and related papers series was processed by Records and Accessioning Archivist, Jane Kelly, in January 2022. Materials were bagged using Bagger and ingested to the Tufts Digital Library. Received order was maintained. A file-level inventory was created, and series and collection-level description were updated at the time of processing.
Box 30 (barcode 39090010625495) could not be found as of June 19, 2017.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This record group contains the administrative records--including correspondence, financial reocrds, newspaper clippings, photographs, publications, reports, speeches, and subject files--of the presidents of Tufts. Information about all aspects of the college and university are found in the records of the Office of the President. Often this material is in summary form. Records prior to 1976 were inconsistently kept and are even less complete for nineteenth-century presidents.
Most of the collections of the early presidents contain personal correspondence, teaching material, and writings.
Materials regarding John P. Marshall (acting president, 1861-1862) are located in his vertical file.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Office of the President is responsible for regulating and overseeing the general administration of the University. Along with various administrative duties, each year the president prepares an annual report which is delivered to the Board of Trustees. This state of the university report generally includes information about past and present college affairs and policies, as well as future plans and suggestions. The Office of the President was the first, and for a time only, administrative office. Originally, the president performed virtually all administrative duties. Presidents usually were members of the faculty as well. In the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, as administrative functions became more complex, the duties of the president were spread among other administrators. With the professionalization of college and university administration in the mid-twentieth century, specialized administrative offices were created, and faculty no longer performed dual roles of educators and administrators.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection contains some restricted material. Restrictions related to specific material are listed in the detailed contents list. This collection may require review before it is available for use. Please contact DCA for further details.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. Copyright to all materials created by Tufts University employees in the course of their work is held by the Trustees of Tufts University.

scopecontent.head: Content Warning
scopecontent.p: This finding aid contains language that may be offensive or outdated. Because such language is in titles or direct transcription of published materials, it has not been changed. Keeping this language intact provides the most accurate depiction of the creators' intent, and can potentially tell us important things about bigotry and bias on the part of the creators, or in a particular historical context. It can also preserve terms formerly applied by a group to self-identify that have since fallen out of common usage. For more information on DCA's content warning policy please visit our website.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains the earliest records of teaching at Tufts, photographs, personal correspondence between Ballou and, especially, T.J. Sawyer, as well as some teaching material and some of Ballou's own school books. Dates range from the early 1820s through Ballou's death in 1861. Photographs date from 1858 through 1952. The student records include a recitation (grade) book from about 1854, and records of absences from 1856-61. Teaching material includes notes from lectures on, for example, "The Fall of Rome," "History of the English Language," and "Questions from Bowens Politial Economy." There is one folder of photographs that were added to the collection at some later point. These include original and copy photographic prints (dates are assigned based on the original image) of Ballou, his homestead in Vermont, and various memorials to him at Tufts.
Biographical Note:

Hosea Ballou (1796-1861) was born in Guilford, Vermont in 1796. He was a Universalist clergyman, theologian, and historian. He presided over the parishes of Roxbury and Medford Massachusetts from 1821-1852, published the "Ancient History of Universalism" in 1829, and received an honorary Doctorate of Divinity from, and became an Overseer of, Harvard University in 1845. Having been one of the biggest influences in the establishment of the College, Hosea Ballou 2d became the first President of Tufts College in 1853. He was its first professor of History and Intellectual Philosophy. It would be thirty years after his death before another professor at Tufts was able to match his scholarly and teaching ability in that field. Hosea Ballou 2d established the college's first curriculum which led to the Bachelor of Arts degree. He died in office in 1861. His personal library remains as a legacy to the university to this day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This balance was constructed by the well known maker of philosophical instruments, E.S. Ritchie, 313 Washington St., Boston. The First Universalist Church was located in the North End of Boston at the corner of Hanover and N. Bennett Streets. In 1857 the minister of the church was the Rev. Sebastian Streeter, who undoubtedly was solicited by the president of the college, Hosea Ballou II for financial aid in initiating the study of science at the small struggling college on the Hill in Medford.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains genealogy, Miner estate account books, newsclippings, correspondence from 1859-1895, published speeches and sermons given by Miner, photographs, and a large amount of materials dealing with Alonzo Amos Miner's involvement in the Temperance movement, relief committees, and peace congresses of the mid-to-late nineteenth century. Organizations covered in this collection include the National Prohibition Alliance and the American Total Abstinence Society. Photographic prints dated from 1866 to 1939 include original and copy photographic prints (dates are assigned based on the original image) of Miner and his family coat of arms.

All material accessioned prior to 1997 was arranged by subject, and no attempt was made to recreate original order. Material relating to administering the collection was removed to the documentation files of the collection in the archives.
Biographical note:

Alonzo Ames Miner (1814-95) was born in Lempster, NH, on August 17, 1814. As a young man, Miner taught school in various rural towns in Vermont and New Hampshire. In 1839 he was ordained a Universalist minister. In 1848 he succeeded Hosea Ballou (the elder) as pastor of the Second Universalist Church of Boston, a post he held until his death. Although Miner had little formal education himself, he was firmly devoted to the cause of education in Massachusetts at all levels. He was at various times a member of the Board of Trustees of Tufts College, the Board of Overseers of Harvard, the Massachusetts State Board of Education and other secular and religious educational institutions.

Alonzo Miner was involved in many moral and civic organizations. He was very active in the Temperance movement of the mid-nineteenth century on a local and national level, local work relief committees, national and state peace congresses, and other local civic groups.

Miner was appointed president of Tufts College in 1862, after the untimely death the previous year of Hosea Ballou, 2d. According to the terms of the agreement, Miner continued to hold his position at the Second Universalist Church and received no salary for serving as the president of the college. He is the only president not to live on campus. Miner brought the college back from the brink of financial ruin, and developed many new educational programs. He died on June 14, 1895.

did.unittitle: Elmer Hewitt Capen, administrative records and related papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence from 1854-1903; clippings; Elmer Capen's Inauguration materials from 1875; his writings and publications from 1872-1902; photographs; and correspondence, notices, and memorial publications on the occasion of his death in 1905. Photographs, dating from 1875 through 1889, include original and copy photographic prints (dates are assigned based on the original image) of Capen.

Elmer Hewitt Capen (1838-1905) was born on April 5, 1838 in Stoughton, Massachusetts. He graduated from Tufts in 1860, practiced law for a short time, and then became a Universalist minister. While still an undergraduate, Capen was elected to, and served in, the Massachusetts House of Representatives. He relinquished his seat after one term in order to finish his studies and graduate with his class.

did.unittitle: Frederick William Hamilton, administrative records and related papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains correspondence from 1905-12, clippings, F.W. Hamilton's published writings from 1906-1912, 1906 inauguration material, and photographs. Photographs, dating from 1880, are largely undated and include original and copy photographic prints (dates are assigned based on the original image) of Hamilton and a painted portrait of him.

Frederick William Hamilton (1860-1940) was born in Portland, Maine in 1860. He graduated from Tufts in 1880 with his A.B. and in 1886 with his A.M. in English literature and philosophy. He received an honorary D.D. from Tufts College in 1889, and an honorary LL.D. from St. Lawrence in 1906. He was a Universalist clergyman, businessman, and president of Tufts from 1905-1912.

did.unittitle: William Leslie Hooper, administrative records and related papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains photographs; personal and administrative correspondence; and papers by W.L. Hooper on venereal diseases, and the effects of magnetism on specific heat. The photographs, dating from the 1880s and 90s, are largely undated and include original cabinet cards and copy photographic prints (dates are assigned based on the original image). Most are formal portraits of Hooper.

William Leslie Hooper (1855-1918) was born in Halifax, Nova Scotia in 1855. He received his A.B. from Tufts in 1877, and his A.M. in 1878. Hooper also received an honorary PhD. in 1898 and an LL.D. in 1915. He was instructor of Mathematics and Applied Physics at Bromfield Academy and became its principal in 1880. In 1883 he became assistant professor of physics at Tufts. In 1890, W.L. Hooper became professor of electrical engineering. Having been commended by the Trustees for his contributions to the engineering department at Tufts and his successful fundraising abilities, Professor Hooper was made acting president of Tufts in 1912. He returned to his position in the electrical engineering department in 1914. In addition to his teaching duties, Professor Hooper continued to write extensively in the field of electrical engineering and worked actively as an electrical consultant for many area companies. W.L. Hooper died in his home on Professors Row in 1918.

did.unittitle: Hermon Carey Bumpus, administrative records and related papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains newspaper clippings, photographs, correspondence, programs, reports, and publications relating to Bumpus' inauguration and tenure as President. There is one folder of published articles. The photographs, dating from the 1890s, are largely undated and include original cabinet cards and copy photographic prints (dates are assigned based on the original image). Most are formal portraits of Bumpus. Many others are "candid" shots of Tufts during WWI. Some of the photos were originally in the collection of M.S. Munro.

Hermon Carey Bumpus (1862-1943) was born in Maine in 1862. He received a Ph.B. from Brown in 1884, specializing in biology and science. He began graduate work at Brown before going on to teach at Olivet College in Michigan. Bumpus received his Phd. from Clark University in 1891 and then went on to become professor of Comparative Zoology at Brown. Bumpus received an honorary Doctor of Science from Tufts in 1905 and an honorary LL.D. from Clark in 1909. He directed the Marine Biological Laboratory at Woods Hole and the American Museum of Natural History. Doctor Bumpus became President of Tufts in 1915, after serving as Business Manager of the University of Wisconsin. He was the first President that was not a Universalist, and who had been chosen specifically because of his educational and administrative experience.

did.unittitle: John Albert Cousens, administrative records and related papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains correspondence from 1906-38; presidential and departmental reports from 1927 and 1920; certificates of membership in various organizations; receipts of donations; copies of addresses and speeches given by Cousens between 1923 and 1936; and correspondence, speeches, and clippings on the occasion of Cousens' death in 1937.The photographs, the earliest date from the 1890s, are largely undated and include original cabinet cards and copy photographic prints (dates are assigned based on the original image). Most are formal portraits of Cousens. Some of the photos were originally in the collection of M.S. Munro.

John Albert Cousens (1874-1937) was born in Brookline, Massachusetts on November 17, 1874. He received his A.B. from Tufts College in 1898. He became the Vice-President of the Metropolitan Coal Company of Boston and a Trustee of the College. Cousens also served as a member of the Finance and Executive Committees. He became acting president of Tufts in 1919. In 1920, J.A. Cousens became president of the college. Cousens received an LL.D. from Lombard College and St. Lawrence University. He is credited with having brought the college through the Depression years unharmed. He was instrumental in the establishment of the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy and the New England Medical Center. He died while still in office in 1937.

did.unittitle: George Stewart Miller, administrative records and related papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains correspondence from 1912-74; clippings; press releases; biographical sketches; publications, including Miller's A Brief History of Medford, published in 1917; photographs; testimonials; and the guestbook from a 1956 dinner honoring Miller. The correspondence spans Miller's career at Tufts and includes letters to his wife on the occasion of his death. The photographs, the earliest of which date from 1906, are largely undated and include original and copy photographic prints (dates are assigned based on the original image). Most are formal portraits of Miller. Some of the photos were originally in the collection of M.S. Munro.

George Stewart Miller (1884-1971) was born in Lawrence, Massachusetts in 1884. He received an A.B. from Tufts College in 1906 and an A.M. in 1907. He received an honorary LL.D. from Tufts in 1941. Miller was a teacher of physics and history at Concord High School, 1907-09; assistant principal at Monson Academy, 1909-12; head of the history department, Medford High School, 1912-16; government professor at Tufts College, 1916-56; secretary to president, Tufts College, 1916-19; assistant to president, 1919-37; acting president, Tufts College, 1937-38; vice-president, Dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, Tufts College, 1939-51; chairman of the Department of Government, 1939-56; Dean of Administration, Tufts University, 1951-56; and President, Tufts Alumni Association, 1954-60. Upon his retirement as Dean of Administration, he was awarded the distinction of Dean Emeritus. Throughout his career at Tufts, he advocated for the establishment of faculty pensions and retirement ages. George Stewart Miller died in 1971.

Leonard Carmichael, administrative records and related papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence, government publications, press releases, clippings, and photographs. Dates are 1920-(1938-52)-74. The majority of these records were created in the course of Leonard Carmichael's presidency, 1938-52. The collection contains materials relating to Carmichael's attendance at Tufts, his term as its president, activities at the university during those years, his employment as secretary of the Smithsonian, and his many activities as a professional psychologist. Significant events represented include Tufts involvement in WWII. There are no restrictions on access to this collection.

Leonard Carmichael (1898-1973) was born on November 9, 1898. He received his B.S. from Tufts in 1920 and his Phd. from Harvard in 1924. He became a member of the faculty at Brown in 1926. In 1938, having established himself as a prominent psychologist, Leonard Carmichael became president of Tufts. During his term as president, the college expanded physically, financially, and in enrollment. Another major contribution made by President Carmichael was that of time, research, scholarship, and resources made by the college as part of the World War II war effort. In 1952, after serving as president of Tufts for 14 years, Leonard Carmichael became secretary for the Smithsonian Institution. In 1964 he left the Smithsonian to become vice-president for research and exploration for National Geographic. Leonard Carmichael died in 1973.

did.unittitle: Nils Yngve Wessell, administrative records and related papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence, articles, speeches, subject files, clippings, and photographs documenting Nils Y. Wessell's many duties at Tufts University, focusing on his presidency (1953-66). Correspondence dates from 1947-82, though the bulk dates from 1955-66. Drafts of articles and speeches mainly intended for the Tufts community date from 1940-73. Subject files cover topics such as Wessell's inaguration and resignation, the Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps (NROTC), Carnegie self-studies, and the many awards and honors bestowed on Wessell. Clippings document highlights of Wessell's career. In some instances, correspondence is interfiled with other materials in the subject files. Black and white photographic prints, created mainly for publicity purposes, show Wessell at work and attending various events throughout his many years of service at Tufts.

Nils Yngve Wessell (1914- ) was born in Warren, Pennsylvania on April 14, 1914. He received his B.S. from Lafeyette College in 1934, his M.S. from Brown University in 1935, and his Ph.D. from the University of Rochester in 1938. He was awarded honorary degrees from Lafeyette College, Lesley College, Boston University, Boston College, Northeastern University, Brown University, and Brandeis University. He was the resident psychologist at the Bradley Home in Providence, Rhode Island from 1936 to 1937. From 1938 to 1939, he served as the director of the Mobile Child Guidance Center at the University of Michigan. He was a professor of psychology at Tufts University from 1939 to 1947. In 1943, he was a lecturer in psychology at Harvard University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two letters, one dating from 1995 and one from 1996, were added to this folder on February 21, 2014; letters had been sent to DCA by Dr. Sumner H. Hoffman to be included in the Wessell papers.

did.unittitle: Leonard Chapin Mead, administrative records and related papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence, writings, speeches, public relations materials, biographical materials, clippings, and black and white photographs documenting Leonard C. Mead's career at Tufts University. Correspondence dates from 1940 to 1974, but focuses on Mead's duties as acting president from 1966 to 1967. Various materials document Tufts' self-study during Mead's presidency. Writings and speeches include both published and unpublished works. Clippings cover all aspects of Mead's career. Photographs, apparently generated mainly for publicity purposes, show Mead posed and at special events.

Leonard Chapin Mead (1913- ) was born in Milford, Massachusetts on December 28, 1913. He received an A.B. from Dartmouth College in 1936, a M.A. (1937) and a Ph.D. (1939) from the University of Rochester, and a L.H.D. from Tufts University in 1967. He held a variety of teaching positions in the Psychology Department at Tufts, starting in 1939, until his retirement in 1976. From 1953 to 1959 he served as the dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences. From 1959 to 1966, he was the senior vice president and provost. He was acting president from 1966 to 1967, after which he resumed his former duties. In 1968, he took a leave of absence to serve as the project specialist for the Ford Foundation at the University of Delhi in India. He returned to Tufts in 1971 and retired in 1979.

did.unittitle: Burton Crosby Hallowell, administrative records and related papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Burton Crosby Hallowell (1915-2006) was born in Orleans, Massachusetts, on May 2, 1915. He received both a B.A. (1936) and M.A. (1938) from Wesleyan University and his P.H.D. (1949) from Princeton University as well as honorary L.H.D. degrees from Wesleyan University and Boston University (1969), honorary LL. D. degrees from Northeastern University (1973) and American International College (1975), and an honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from Tufts University (1976). He worked as an assistant professor of economics at Wesleyan from 1941-1942, before working for the United States' Office of Strategic Services in 1942 and the U.S. Army from 1942-1946. From 1946-1950, Hallowell was assistant professor of economics, from 1950-1956 associate professor, and from 1956-1967 Andrews Professor of Economics at Wesleyan. Hallowell served as Wesleyan's Vice President for Planning and Development from 1962-1965, as well as Executive Vice President from 1965-1967.

He was elected 9th president of Tufts in 1967. In the first year of Hallowell's presidency, Tufts ran a large deficit, and projected further deficits over the next few years. President Hallowell used his economic background to control expenses and pursue more donations. By the end of his term, the budget was balanced, and Tufts had received an unprecedented amount of donations.

Hallowell's presidency coincided with a period of social unrest and student activism. Hallowell worked to keep trustees and students thoroughly informed. He gave free rein to student and campus publications. He allowed military recruiting on campus but protested when Selective Service threatened to revoke deferments of students who worked to end the draft. Hallowell established the President's Council for Women and Minorities. In 1973, he appointed a woman as Tufts provost and senior vice president.

Hallowell also pushed to unite Tufts' disparate schools, colleges, and faculties. He urged that graduate education and research activities should be more integrated with undergraduate programs. Moreover, he strongly believed that education ought to develop all aspects of an individual.

He was a consultant and trustee of various institutions including e.g., Connecticut General Life Insurance Co., the board of governors of the Tufts New England Medical Center, and the Commission of Economic Development, New York City. In addition, he was the first chairman of the Massachusetts Housing Finance Agency. Throughout his career Hallowell consulted, wrote articles, and gave speeches on economic topics.

Hallowell resigned his presidency in 1976. Afterward he served as chairman of Keystone Custodian Funds and a director of 7 corporations. He helped found Friends of the Cape Cod National Seashore and was a trustee of Cape Cod Museum of Natural History. He died Nov. 21, 2006.
References:
Partial Resume and Biographical Record, both in Vertical Files, B. H. Hallowell;

"Tufts' 9th President Guided Institution through Tumultuous Times", Tufts Journal, http://tuftsjournal.tufts.edu/archive/2007/january/features/hallowell_tribute.shtml (no byline) Russell E. Miller, Light on the Hill vol.II, p. 258-390. Keystone Funds information is from http://www.princeton.edu/~paw/archive_new/PAW06-07/12-0411/memorials.html

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of correspondence documenting Burton C. Hallowell's presidency, from 1967-1976. The large majority of the correspondence is authored by Hallowell and provides a detailed, daily account of his duties. Letters received were presumably placed throughout the Subject Files. A few letters exist illustrating Hallowell's relationship with the University following his retirement, dating as late as 1988.

did.unittitle: Sheetz, John W. (Administration) (3) [Advance Proof of the 1975 alumni opinion survey]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder was found uncataloged in stacks. It contains an advance proof of John W. Sheetz' Report on the Dec. 1975 Opinion Survey. The newspaper publication of this report can by found in UA042.001.019.00002. This reports includes alumni opinions on many hot topics of the time, including homosexuality, co-ed dorms, affirmative action, alumni communications, attitudes re: Tufts, fraternaties/sororities, sex discrimination, admission, faculty. Also includes transcribed quotes from respondants on the topics of ROTC, social attitudes, and fund raising. The results of this survey give a great overview of the opinions of alumni of various age groups in 1975.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of articles and speeches authored by Burton C. Hallowell during his presidency (1967-1976). These include addresses given at functions such as Hallowell's inauguration, commencements, conferences, and meetings of associations. The speeches appear in the form of drafts, transcripts, and reprints and greatly outnumber Hallowell's published works. Articles include works written for the Boston Globe and Tufts publications on liberal arts education.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of newspaper clippings documenting various aspects of Burton C. Hallowell's presidency (1967-1976) at Tufts. Topics represented include Hallowell's inauguration and resignation, the Tufts student body, and student unrest. Many of the clippings have been cut out of newspapers and pasted to sheets of paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of subject files containing memoranda, reports, correspondence, clippings, committee records, and related materials documenting the duties and events of the Burton C. Hallowell presidential administration at Tufts University. These files were previously arranged and no attempt has been made to reconstruct original order. Much of the University's committee work of the time is represented in this series, which includes the records of the University Steering Committee (USC), the Committee on Undergraduate Education (CUE), the Presidential Administrative Advisory Group (PAAG), and the Association of Independent Colleges and Universities of Massachusetts (AICUM). The administration of select schools and programs, most notably the Tufts New England Medical Center, is documented. Events, such as a lecture by Senator Edward Kennedy and the "Construction Site Crisis," are also represented.

Jean Mayer, administrative records and related papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials which document Dr. Jean Mayer's presidency of Tufts University (1976-1992), his involvement in local, national, and international issues and organizations subsequent to his arrival at Tufts, and his career as a nutritionist and educator.

The Subject files group contains correspondence, memoranda, reports, clippings, proposals, research, books, photographs, and background materials concerning the diverse subjects of Mayer's career. Also included in this series are articles, addresses, lectures, columns, public letters and related correspondence authored by Mayer in his capacities as nutritionist and university president.

The bulk of the Subject files concern Mayer's presidency of Tufts University, during which Tufts was transformed from a small liberal arts college into a research university with an international reputation. The subjects of these files range from the routine administrative duties of a university president to projects masterminded by Mayer, including the development of the Graduate School of Nutrition, the first in the United States, the School of Veterinary Medicine, first of its kind in New England, the Tufts United States Department of Agriculture Nutrition Research Center on Aging in Boston, and the Center for Environmental Management.

The Subject files also include files concerning local, national, and international organizations and issues of interest to Mayer subsequent to his arrival at Tufts. Local organizations and issues in these files include in part the Children's Hospital of Boston, Boston school desegregation, and the New England Board of Higher Education.

The bulk of the files concerning issues and organizations on the national level pertain to the U.S. Government. These files concern in part Mayer's role in the Presidential Commission on World Hunger (1978-1980), his testimony before congressional committees as an expert on hunger and nutrition, his involvement in the 20th-anniversary commemoration of the 1969 White House Conference on Food, Nutrition and Health, and his dealings with various facets of the U.S. Government on legislative matters concerning nutrition and funding for education.

Many files in the Subject files concern Mayer's involvement and interest in international organizations and issues. As chairman of the New England Board of Higher Education, Mayer established a scholarship fund for black students from South Africa (1985). As President of Tufts, Mayer developed the Niger Range and Livestock Project and initiated a global classroom project involving Tufts and Moscow State universities (1985). Mayer also created an international association of university presidents, the Talloires University Presidents Group, which addressed issues of arms control, negotiation and conflict management, higher education in apartheid South Africa, and the environment in annual conferences from 1988-1990. As an expert on hunger and nutrition, Mayer studied famine in Sudan, advised the Food and Agriculture Organization and World Health Organization of the United Nations, and chaired a task force on children's priorities for the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF).

Over the course of his career, Mayer wrote prolifically and lectured widely on topics ranging from physiological chemistry and human nutrition to U.S. domestic and foreign policy. Included in this series are many of the articles Mayer published between 1972-1992 as well as drafts of these articles and correspondence relating to their publication. Also included in this series are lectures, speeches, and addresses delivered by Mayer on various occasions subsequent to his arrival at Tufts.
Also included are the newspaper column titled Food for Thought and written by Jean Mayer. Some of the columns were co-authored by Joanna Dwyer (1976) and Jeanne Goldberg (ca. 1981).

Mayer's files also include unprocessed materials relating to his father, Andre Mayer. These include foreign language publications, correspondence, articles, photographs, cassette tapes, a VHS tape, personal calendars, and hoods.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Subject files are arranged alphabetically. Other files in this series are not arranged.

did.unittitle: John DiBiaggio, administrative records and related papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence, memoranda, reports and general subject files documenting the presidency of John DiBiaggio. The bulk of the material focuses on DiBiaggio's duties and activities as president. There are little or no materials on his positions held elsewhere or other aspects of his career. Dr. John DiBiaggio served as the eleventh president of Tufts University from 1992 to 2002.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is organized into four subseries: Subject files; Correspondence; Speeches; and Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of subject files containing memoranda, correspondence, reports and related materials documenting the duties and events of John DiBiaggio's presidency at Tufts University. Also included are subject files from the Jean Mayer presidency. These files have been combined with those of DiBiaggios in an effort to maintain original order.

did.unittitle: President DiBiaggio with past presidents of Michigan State University

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original photo undated. This photograph was originally published in the MSU News-Bulletin on November 16, 1989 and is credited to Bruce Cox. The caption for the photo in that issue reads "'Past and Present Leaders' Five former MSU presidents joined President DiBiaggio Nov. 9 in a private ceremony for the unveiling of their portraits in the Board Room of the Administration Building. From left are Edgar Harden, president from 1978-1979; DiBiaggio, president since 1985; John Hannah, 1941-1969; Clifton Wharton Jr., 1970-1978; Cecil Mackey, 1979-1985; and Walter Adams, 1969-1970."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Each year the president is required to report to the Board of Trustees on the activities of the previous year. This report, variously called the President's Report, the Annual Report of the President to the Board of Trustees, the President's Annual Report, and The Year in Review, is a summary of all the reports submitted to the president by deans, department heads and administrators. The collection contains the annual reports of the president to the Board of Trustees. The reports of 1919-20 are printed in the Tufts College Graduate, Vol. 18-19.

This series also contains microfilm copies of these reports. Some rolls of microfilm were found to contain materials from multiple creating offices. These rolls are housed in UA193-- University Microfilm Collection. See this collection and its corresponding documentation file for more information.

The president's report is a summary of activities, programs, and accomplishments at the University in the past year. A summary report is published in the Alumni magazine. The complete report generally contains charts, graphs, etc.

Until 1971, the annual reports of the provost, deans and vice presidents were included in the president's report as appendices. Beginning in 1971 these reports were bound separately from the president's report and are cataloged in a related collection, called Administrator's Annual Reports.

did.unittitle: Lawrence Seldon Bacow administrative records and related papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains subject files, correspondence, chronological files, audio-visual materials, photographs, awards, honorary degrees, memorabilia, and gifts related to the presidency of Lawrence S. Bacow. Bacow served as the twelfth president of Tufts University from 2001 to 2011. Of particular interest is the subject files related to Bacow's leadership efforts at Tufts, such as the President's Marathon Challenge, Community outreach programs in Medford and Somerville, and the Talloires Network and conferences. There is also video footage of Bacow's speeches at a number of conferences throughout the country and the world such as the 2006 TIAA-CREF Transformational Change in Higher Education in New York. Also of interest are videos of his inauguration and a video address he recorded to speak in opposition to an attempt by the United Auto Workers (UAW) to unionize graduate students at Tufts University, circa 2002.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged into six sub-series: Subject files; Chronological files; General correspondence; Audio-visual materials, Photographic materials; and Awards, gifts, and memorabilia.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series contains some restricted material. Restrictions related to specific material are listed in the detailed contents list

arrangement.head: Arrangement

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains VHS tapes related to Bacow's presidency. Of particular interest is a video address that Lawrence Bacow recorded to express his opposition to efforts of the United Auto Workers to unionize graduate students at Tufts, circa 2002. Also of interest are videos of Bacow's inauguration ceremony in 2002.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access

did.unittitle: President Bacow - Tape 1 - Video Address About UAW unionization efforts at Tufts

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: 75 years from the date of creation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tufts University President Lawrence Bacow speaking about the efforts of United Auto Workers to organize Tufts graduate students into a union. The United Auto Workers submitted a petition to the National Labor Relations Board to organize Tufts graduate students, teaching and research assistants into a union. Bacow was opposed to the formation of a union and filmed this video address to share his views.

The United Auto Workers submitted a petition to the National Labor Relations Board to organize Tufts graduate students, teaching and research assistants into a union. Bacow was opposed to the formation of a union and filmed this video address, directed to graduate students, to share his views.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains awards, gifts, and memorabilia that Lawrence Bacow received during his presidency at Tufts. Of particular interest is an official letter from Barack Obama appointing Lawrence Bacow as a member of the President's Board of Advisors on Historically Black Colleges and Universities. Also of note is the memorabilia, such as posters, buttons, and other promotional items for Tufts University's 150th Anniversary celebration in 2002.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This sub-series is arranged into three sub-subseries: Awards, gifts, and memorabilia; Inauguration congratulations; and Sesquicentennial celebration memorabilia.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This sub-series contains some restricted material. Restrictions related to specific material are listed in the detailed contents list.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-subseries contains awards, gifts, and memorabilia that Lawrence Bacow received during his presidency at Tufts. Of particular interest is an official letter from Barack Obama appointing Lawrence Bacow as a member of the President's Board of Advisors on Historically Black Colleges and Universities. Also of interest is an 1835 letter from Hosea Ballou that was given to Lawrence Bacow as a gift.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This sub-subseries is arranged alphabetically by folder title, where possible. Material of varying size (i.e. oversized, material that cannot be foldered, etc) is not arranged.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access

did.unittitle: Presidential Inauguration congratulation letters and correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-subseries contains correspondence and official congratulatory letters that Lawrence Bacow received from several dozen universities to congratulate him on his inauguration as President of Tufts University in April 2002. Of particular interest are congratulatory letters from two of Bacow's alma mater institutions, Harvard University and Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This sub-subseries is arranged alphabetically by folder title, with the exception of legal sized folders, which are arranged at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This digital object contains photographs and other digital files from the website for President Bacow's conference, entitled "The Civic Engagement Roles and Responsibilities of Higher Education." This conference was hosted by Tufts University in September 15-17, 2005 at the Tufts University European Center in Talloires, France.
